questions.title: I
questions.article:
Solar time is determined by the position of the Sun relative to a meridian (an imaginary line that passes through the northernmost and southernmost points of the horizon, dividing the visible sky into 2 equal halves). At solar noon, the Sun appears to cross the meridian. A solar day is the period between one solar noon and the next. Because the Sun’s apparent motion is not uniform, a solar day is generally not the same length as a mean day, which is exactly 24 hrs (1,440 min). See Figure 1.


Figure 2 shows how the difference between solar time and mean time (time as indicated by a clock) varies throughout the year.
questions.question: 1. Based on Figure 2, on how many dates each year is solar time exactly 8 minutes behind mean time?

questions.title: I
questions.article:
Solar time is determined by the position of the Sun relative to a meridian (an imaginary line that passes through the northernmost and southernmost points of the horizon, dividing the visible sky into 2 equal halves). At solar noon, the Sun appears to cross the meridian. A solar day is the period between one solar noon and the next. Because the Sun’s apparent motion is not uniform, a solar day is generally not the same length as a mean day, which is exactly 24 hrs (1,440 min). See Figure 1.


Figure 2 shows how the difference between solar time and mean time (time as indicated by a clock) varies throughout the year.
questions.question: 2.  According to Figure 2, on which of the following dates does solar time have the same value as mean time?

choices.D: July 1

questions.title: I
questions.article:
Solar time is determined by the position of the Sun relative to a meridian (an imaginary line that passes through the northernmost and southernmost points of the horizon, dividing the visible sky into 2 equal halves). At solar noon, the Sun appears to cross the meridian. A solar day is the period between one solar noon and the next. Because the Sun’s apparent motion is not uniform, a solar day is generally not the same length as a mean day, which is exactly 24 hrs (1,440 min). See Figure 1.


Figure 2 shows how the difference between solar time and mean time (time as indicated by a clock) varies throughout the year.
questions.question: 3. During the first 6 months of the year, is solar time more often ahead of mean time or behind mean time?

choices.A: Ahead; the difference between solar time and mean time is more often positive during the first 6 months of the year.
choices.B: Ahead; the difference between solar time and mean time is more often negative during the first 6 months of the year.
choices.C: Behind; the difference between solar time and mean time is more often positive during the first 6 months of the year.
choices.D: Behind; the difference between solar time and mean time is more often negative during the first 6 months of the year.

questions.question: 4. According to Figure 1, on which of the following dates is the solar day longer than the mean day?

choices.D: August 15

questions.question: 5. According to Figure 2, in a given year, solar time is head of mean time for approximately how many months in total?

questions.title: I

questions.question: 6. Based on Figure 1, the longest solar day of the year is approximately how much longer than the shortest solar day of the year?

choices.D: 1.6 min

questions.title: II
questions.article:
An experiment was conducted to determine how seawater temperature and salinity affect food consumption and growth in Scophthalmus maximus (a species of fish). The table shows, for each of 8 trials, average total food consumption, CT, and average gain in body mass for S. maximus kept at various temperature and salinity combinations. Bach trial involved the same number of fish and lasted the same number of months.


Table adapted from Albert K. Imsland et al., "The Interaction of Temperature and Salinity on Growth and Food Conversion in Juvenile Turbot (Scophthalmus maximus)."@2001 by Elsevier Science B. V.
questions.question: 7. Based on the table, for which 2 trials was the average CT value less than 50 g and the average gain in body mass greater than 75 g?

choices.D: Trial 3 and Trial 7

questions.title: II
questions.article:
An experiment was conducted to determine how seawater temperature and salinity affect food consumption and growth in Scophthalmus maximus (a species of fish). Bach trial involved the same number of fish and lasted the same number of months.


Table adapted from Albert K. Imsland et al., "The Interaction of Temperature and Salinity on Growth and Food Conversion in Juvenile Turbot (Scophthalmus maximus)."@2001 by Elsevier Science B. V.
questions.question: 8.  Consider Trials 1-4. Based on the table, as salinity increased, did average CT increase or decrease, and did average gain in body mass increase or decrease?

choices.A: average CT : increase average gain in body mass: decrease
choices.B: average CT : increase average gain in body mass: increase
choices.C: average CT : decrease average gain in body mass: decrease
choices.D: average CT : decrease average gain in body mass: increase

questions.question: 9. Consider the 4 trials for which the average CT values were less than 45 g. What is the order of these trials from the trial with the least average CT value to the trial with the greatest average CT value?

choices.D: Trial 7, Trial 4, Trial 6, Trial 5

choices.D: Cannot be determined from the given information

questions.question: 12. What was the average CT, in kilograms (kg), for fish kept at a temperature of 22°C and a salinity of 25 ppt?

questions.title: III
questions.article:
Three studies examined the effects of compost (organic matter) on 3 physical properties of soil.

Five soil mixtures (Mixtures 1-5) were prepared (see Table 1).


Study 1
A 1.5 L pot was prepared by placing 500 g of Mixture 1 into the pot, after which the pot was stored at 30°C for 72 hr. The pot and its contents were then baked in a 105°C oven for 24 hr. After cooling, the mixture's bulk density (the dry mass of the mixture per unit volume) was determined.

These procedures were repeated for each of Mixtures 2-5 (see Table 2).


Study 2
Another 1. 5 L pot of Mixture 1 was prepared, stored, and baked as in Study 1.

The dried mixture was ground into powder and passed through a screen with 2 mm diameter openings. Five grams of the screened powder were then mixed with 5 mL of H2O. and the pH of the powder-H2O suspension was determined.

These procedures were repeated for each of Mixtures 2-5 (see Table 3).


Study 3
Another 1. 5 L pot of Mixture was prepared, stored, and baked as in Study 1. The dried mixture was then ground and screened as in Study 2.

Fifty grams of the screened powder were mixed with 5 mL of H2O to form a soil paste, and the paste was placed on a filter. Suction was then applied to the filter. and the extract (the clear, colorless liquid that passed through the filter) was collected. The electrical conductivity of the extract was determined.

These procedures were repeated for each of Mixtures 2-5 (see Table 4).
questions.question: 13. Which of the following is the most likely reason that a given mixture was exposed to a temperature of 105°C in Study 1?

choices.A: To allow the mixture to be passed through a screen
choices.B: To prevent the mixture from being passed through a screen
choices.C: To add moisture to the mixture
choices.D: To remove moisture from the mixture

questions.question: 14.  In Study 3, once the suction was applied, the filters most likely allowed the passage of:

choices.D: neither soil nor liquid.

questions.question: 15. Based on the results of Study 1, if a mixture with 60% by volume of compost had been tested in Study 1, the bulk density of this mixture would most likely have been:

choices.D: greater than 255 mg/mL.

questions.question: 16.  Study 2 differed from Study 3 in which of the follow ing ways?

choices.A: A greater mass of the screened powder was mixed with H2O in Study 2 than in Study 3.
choices.B: A greater mass of the screened powder was mixed with H2O in Study 3 than in Study 2.
choices.C: A longer storage time was used in Study 2 than in Study 3.
choices.D: A longer storage time was used in Study 3 than in Study 2.

questions.question: 17.  Consider the mixture that resulted in the suspension with the lowest pH in Study 2. According to the results of Study 1, was the bulk density of this mixture greater than, less than, or equal to 150 mg/mL?

choices.D: Cannot be determined from the given information

questions.question: 18.  In Study 2, was the suspension for Mixture 1 acidic or basic?

choices.A: Basic, because the pH was greater than 7.0.
choices.B: Basic, because the pH was less than 7.0.
choices.C: Acidic, because the pH was greater than 7.0.
choices.D: Acidic, because the pH was less than 7.0.

questions.article:
Three studies examined the effects of compost (organic matter) on 3 physical properties of soil.

Five soil mixtures (Mixtures 1-5) were prepared (see Table 1).


Study 1

questions.question: 19. Consider the statement "The percent by volume of compost in the mixture that had the greatest bulk density was the same as the percent by volume of compost in the mixture that had the extract with the lowest electrical conductivity." Do the results of Studies 1 and 3 support this statement?

choices.A: Yes; 50% by volume of compost resulted in the greatest bulk density and the lowest electrical conductivity.
choices.B: Yes; 95% by volume of compost resulted in the greatest bulk density and the lowest electrical conductivity.
choices.C: No; 50% by volume of compost resulted in the greatest bulk density, but 95% by volume of compost resulted in the lowest electrical conductivity.
choices.D: No; 95% by volume of compost resulted in the greatest bulk density, but 50% by volume of compost resulted in the lowest electrical conductivity.

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
When a sand-covered drumhead vibrates at certain frequencies, the sand collects at nodes (areas of least vibration). Two types of nodes can form on a vibrating drumhead: radial nodes, which look like rings, and linear nodes, which look like straight lines. As sand collects at nodes, patterns called nodal patterns (NPs) form. Figure 1 shows two NPs that can form on a sand-covered drumhead: NP 1 (a radial node only) and NP 2 (a radial node and a linear node).


Students performed 2 experiments to study the formation of NP 1 and NP 2 on various drumheads.

Experiment 1

The students obtained 5 drumheads, each having a different diameter and each set to a tension of 2,000 newtons per meter (N/m). They performed a trial with each drumhead, using the following procedure: First, they placed the drumhead directly above a speaker emitting sound waves having a frequency of 90 hertz (Hz). Then, they gradually increased the frequency until they observed NP 1. Finally, they continued to increase the frequency until they observed NP 2. Throughout each trial, the amplitude (loudness) of the sound waves was held constant. Table 1 shows the frequency at which the students observed NP 1 and NP 2 for each trial.


Experiment 2

The students performed 7 more trials with the 50 cm diameter drumhead. In each trial, first the tension was adjusted to a certain value, and then the procedures of the Experiment 1 trials were repeated. Figure 2 shows the results for each trial, as well as a line of best fit for each NP.
questions.question: 20. Based on the results of Experiment 1, for how many of the diameters tested was the frequency for NP 1 less than that for NP 2 ?

questions.title: IV
questions.article:

Experiment 2

questions.question: 21. Which of the following questions about either drumhead diameter or drumhead tension can be answered by the results of Experiment 2 ? What effect did the:

choices.A: diameter of the drumhead have on the frequency at which the NPs were observed?
choices.B: diameter of the drumhead have on the time at which the NPs were observed?
choices.C: tension of the drumhead have on the frequency at which the NPs were observed?
choices.D: tension of the drumhead have on the time at which the NPs were observed?

questions.question: 22.  Suppose that in Experiment 2 a trial had been performed in which NP 1 was observed at a frequency of 130 Hz. Based on Figure 2, the tension of the drumhead would most likely have been closest to which of the following?

questions.article:

questions.question: 23. Experiments 1 and 2 differed in which of the following ways? In Experiment 1:

choices.A: loudness was held constant and frequency was varied, whereas in Experiment 2, loudness was varied and frequency was held constant.
choices.B: loudness was varied and frequency was held constant, whereas in Experiment 2, loudness was held constant and frequency was varied.
choices.C: 5 drumheads were used, whereas in Experiment 2, 1 drumhead was used.
choices.D: 5 drumheads were used, whereas in Experiment 2, 7 drumheads were used.

questions.article:

questions.question: 24. Based on the results of Experiment 1, for the 60 cm diameter drumhead. what was the difference between the frequency at which NP 1 was observed and the frequency at which the speaker was initially set during the procedure?

choices.D: 178 Hz

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
When a sand-covered drumhead vibrates at certain frequencies, the sand collects at nodes (areas of least vibration). Two types of nodes can form on a vibrating drumhead: radial nodes, which look like rings, and linear nodes, which look like straight lines. As sand collects at nodes, patterns called nodal patterns (NPs) form. Figure 1 shows two NPs that can form on a sand-covered drumhead: NP 1 (a radial node only) and NP 2 (a radial node and a linear node).


Students performed 2 experiments to study the formation of NP 1 and NP 2 on various drumheads.

Experiment 1

The students obtained 5 drumheads, each having a different diameter and each set to a tension of 2,000 newtons per meter (N/m). They performed a trial with each drumhead, using the following procedure: First, they placed the drumhead directly above a speaker emitting sound waves having a frequency of 90 hertz (Hz). Then, they gradually increased the frequency until they observed NP 1. Finally, they continued to increase the frequency until they observed NP 2. Throughout each trial, the amplitude (loudness) of the sound waves was held constant. Table 1 shows the frequency at which the students observed NP 1 and NP 2 for each trial.


Experiment 2

The students performed 7 more trials with the 50 cm diameter drumhead. In each trial, first the tension was adjusted to a certain value, and then the procedures of the Experiment 1 trials were repeated. Figure 2 shows the results for each trial, as well as a line of best fit for each NP.
questions.question: 25. For a given diameter and tension, the fundamental frequency is the frequency at which NP 1 is observed. Suppose that, for a 20 cm diameter drumhead set at a tension of 2.000 N/m, a certain NP is known to form at a frequency that is 2.3 times the fundamental frequency. Based on the results of Experiment 1, this NP would most likely form at approximately what frequency?

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
When a sand-covered drumhead vibrates at certain frequencies, the sand collects at nodes (areas of least vibration). Two types of nodes can form on a vibrating drumhead: radial nodes, which look like rings, and linear nodes, which look like straight lines. As sand collects at nodes, patterns called nodal patterns (NPs) form. Figure 1 shows two NPs that can form on a sand-covered drumhead: NP 1 (a radial node only) and NP 2 (a radial node and a linear node).


Students performed 2 experiments to study the formation of NP 1 and NP 2 on various drumheads.

Experiment 1

The students obtained 5 drumheads, each having a different diameter and each set to a tension of 2,000 newtons per meter (N/m). They performed a trial with each drumhead, using the following procedure: First, they placed the drumhead directly above a speaker emitting sound waves having a frequency of 90 hertz (Hz). Then, they gradually increased the frequency until they observed NP 1. Finally, they continued to increase the frequency until they observed NP 2. Throughout each trial, the amplitude (loudness) of the sound waves was held constant. Table 1 shows the frequency at which the students observed NP 1 and NP 2 for each trial.


Experiment 2

The students performed 7 more trials with the 50 cm diameter drumhead. In each trial, first the tension was adjusted to a certain value, and then the procedures of the Experiment 1 trials were repeated. Figure 2 shows the results for each trial, as well as a line of best fit for each NP.
questions.question: 26. A student claimed that the greater the drumhead diameter, the longer the wavelength of sound needed to observe a given NP. Is this claim supported by the results for NP 2 from Experiment 1?

choices.A: Yes; as the diameter was increased, the frequency at which NP 2 was observed increased.
choices.B: Yes; as the diameter was increased, the frequency at which NP 2 was observed decreased.
choices.C: No; as the diameter was increased, the frequency at which NP 2 was observed increased.
choices.D: No; as the diameter was increased, the frequency at which NP 2 was observed decreased.

questions.title: V
questions.article:
Three students observed that Trait R is present in some people but not in others. The presence or absence of Trait R in a person is determined entirely by alleles of Gene R. Gene R has 2 alleles: R, which is dominant, and r, which is recessive.

A teacher gave the students a pedigree showing the inheritance of Trait R in a particular family (see Figure 1). Each individual represented in the pedigree was assigned a number (shown below the symbol for the individual) for reference. Based on the pedigree, each student proposed a hypothesis explaining the pattern of inheritance for Trait R in this family.


Student 1

Gene R is located on the X chromosome, so females (who inherit two X chromosomes) inherit 2 copies of Gene R, whereas males (who inherit one X chromosome) inherit only 1 copy of Gene R. All females with Trait R inherited 2 copies of the r allele, and all males with Trait R inherited 1 copy of the r allele. Table 1 shows the possible Gene R genotypes for females and for males and indicates whether the genotypes result in Trait R.


Student 2

Gene R is not located on the X chromosome or the Y chromosome. All individuals with Trait R inherited 2 copies of the r allele.

Student 3

Gene R is not located on the X chromosome or the Y chromosome. All individuals with Trait R inherited either 1or 2 copies of the R allele.
questions.question: 27. Which student, if any, would be likely to predict that the Gene R genotype of Individual 5 is rr?

choices.D: None of the students

Student 2

Student 3

questions.question: 28. Which of the following tables is most consistent with the hypothesis of Student 3 ?

Student 3

questions.question: 29. Which of Student 2 or Student 3 implied that Trait R is a recessive trait?

choices.A: Student 2, because Student 2 predicted that individuals with 2 copies of the recessive allele of Gene R will have Trait R.
choices.B: Student 2, because Student 2 predicted that individuals with only 1 copy of the recessive allele of Gene R will have Trait R.
choices.C: Student 3, because Student 3 predicted that individuals with 2 copies of the recessive allele of Gene R will have Trait R.
choices.D: Student 3, because Student 3 predicted that individuals with only 1 copy of the recessive allele of Gene R will have Trait R.

questions.question: 30. Suppose that Individual 20 and Individual 21 have a biological child. Based on Student 2's hypothesis, what is the probability that the child will have Trait R?

questions.question: 31. Based on Student 1's hypothesis, is an individual with the Gene R genotype RR female or male, and does the individual have Trait R?

choices.D: Male; no

questions.question: 32.  Which of the students proposed a pattern of inheritance that would most likely result in Trait R being rarer in females than in males?

choices.D: Student 1, 2, and 3

questions.question: 33. Consider Individuals 3 and 4 and their offspring. Is this portion of the pedigree more consistent with the hypothesis of Student 1 or the hypothesis of Student 3?

choices.A: Student 1; this portion of the pedigree suggests that Trait R is a dominant trait.
choices.B: Student 1; this portion of the pedigree suggests that Trait R is a recessive trait.
choices.C: Student 3; this portion of the pedigree suggests that Trait R is a dominant trait.
choices.D: Student 3; this portion of the pedigree suggests that Trait R is a recessive trait.

questions.title: VI
questions.article:
The hot, spicy flavor of chili peppers is directly proportional to the concentration of capsaicinoids (a class of chemical compounds). Scientists studied the effects of fertilizer application and pepper color on the capsaicinoid concentration of 3 varieties of chili peppers (V1‐V3).

Study

Two hundred V1 plants that were 82 days old were divided into 4 equal groups, and each group was planted in a different plot (Plot L, M, N, or O) in a particular field. This procedure was repeated with V2 and V3 plants in separate, but adjacent, fields. Fertilizer was then applied to the type L plots and the type M plots. Each plot was irrigated equally once every 20 days until harvest. All the peppers in the type L plots and the type N plots were harvested 77 days after planting, while the peppers were still green. All the peppers in the type M plots and the type O plots were harvested 87 days after planting, after the peppers had turned red. Table 1 summarizes, for each plot type, whether fertilizer was applied to the plot and the color of the peppers in the plot at the time of harvest.


Immediately after being harvested, all the peppers were dried at 65°C for 24 hr. Then, for each field, all the dried peppers grown in a given plot were ground up and combine. The total capsaicinord concentration, in miligrams of capsaicinoids per gram of dry pepper (mg/g), was then determined for the peppers from each plot of each field. The results are shown in Table 2.


Tables adapted from Alberto Gonzalez-Zamora et al., “Measurement of Capsaicinolds in Chlltepln Hot Pepper: A Comparison Study between Spectrophotometne Method and High Performance Liquld Chromatography Analysts." @2015 by Alberto Gonzalez-Zamora et al.
questions.question: 34. The hottest peppers in the study were most likely those of which variety grown in which plot?

choices.A: The V2 peppers grown in Plot L, because they had the highest total capsaicinoid content.
choices.B: The V2 peppers grown in Plot L, because they had the lowest total capsaicinoid content.
choices.C: The V3 peppers grown in Plot O, because they had the highest total capsaicinoid content.
choices.D: The V3 peppers grown in Plot O, because they had the lowest total capsaicinoid content.

Tables adapted from Alberto Gonzalez-Zamora et al., “Measurement of Capsaicinolds in Chlltepln Hot Pepper: A Comparison Study between Spectrophotometne Method and High Performance Liquld Chromatography Analysts." @2015 by Alberto Gonzalez-Zamora et al.
questions.question: 35. The spiciness of a pepper is often reported in Scoville heat units (SHU). In general, the higher the total capsaicinoid concentration, the higher the SHU value. Based on the results of the study for V1 in the plots that had fertilizer applied, would the SHU rating likely have been higher for green peppers or for red peppers?

choices.A: Green; the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot L peppers was higher than that of the Plot M peppers.
choices.B: Green; the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot N peppers was higher than that of the Plot O peppers.
choices.C: Red; the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot L peppers was higher than that of the Plot M peppers.
choices.D: Red; the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot N peppers was higher than that of the Plot O peppers.

questions.title: VI
questions.article:

questions.question: 36. Consider the statement "For a given variety of pepper grown without applied fertilizer. the total capsaicinoid concentration of red peppers is generally higher than that of green peppers." Are the results of the study for V3 consistent with this statement?

choices.A: No, because the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot L peppers was higher than that of the Plot M peppers.
choices.B: No, because the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot N peppers was higher than that of the Plot O peppers.
choices.C: Yes, because the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot L peppers was higher than that of the Plot M peppers.
choices.D: Yes, because the total capsaicinoid concentration of the Plot N peppers was higher than that of the Plot O peppers.

questions.question: 37. Assume that 50 kg of fertilizer was applied to each plot that was fertilized in the study. Suppose an additional plot type in which 100 kg of fertilizer was applied to each plot had also been included in the study. The peppers grown in these plots were harvested 77 days after planting in the fields. The results are shown in the following table.Based on the available information, how did the total capsaicinoid concentration of the peppers change as the amount of fertilizer applied changed from 0 kg to 50 kg to 100 kg ? For each pepper variety, the total capsaicinoid concentration:

choices.D: decreased and then increased.

questions.question: 38. For each of the 3 pepper varieties, which plot was most likely intended to serve as the control for the effect of applied fertilizer on peppers that were harvested when they were red?

choices.D: Plot O

choices.D: Cannot be determined from the given information

questions.question: 40. Assume that the average mass of a dried V1 pepper was 20 g. On average, the total mass, in milligrams, of capsaicinoids found in a V1 pepper from Plot M was closest to which of the following?
